facts.text: Suraj Bhan, son of Kashiram, abducted on November 12, 1954, at 7:15 p.m. from his house in Rajgarh while at his desk; two masked men, one with revolver, threatened and took him on camel after tying cloth around his neck; fired shots in air.
Abductors rode for 3-4 hours to railway line, walked 3-4 furlongs, then took Suraj Bhan to Deep Chand's house in village Kalari; confined blindfolded in small room for 17 days.

Two or three days after abduction, Suraj Bhan forced to write three letters to father Kashiram under blanket: first threatening if police informed; second ransom Rs.60,000 due to tracing attempts; third to hand money to bearer.
On November 29, 1954, Suraj Bhan moved to Lachhman's house and confined there till release.

Dhannaram offered help to Kashiram via son-in-law Shiv Bhagwan and Durga Parshad; letter to Deep Chand; negotiations fixed ransom at Rs.50,000; third letter shown; Rs.50,000 paid to Dhannaram and Deep Chand on December 17, 1954; Suraj Bhan released December 20, 1954.
Suraj Bhan identified Deep Chand as one abductor (known local Congressman); recognized voice and stature during confinement.

During confinement in Deep Chand's house, Suraj Bhan loosened bandage, saw through chinks in wall (tree visible, later closed); heard Deep Chand's voice and ladies talking; landmarks matched journey to Deep Chand's house.
Magistrate Devisingh conducted verification at Deep Chand's house: plan Ex.P-28, memorandum Ex.P-27; chinks recently closed, new rooms constructed north side beginning 1955.
Lachhman (W.3) kept Suraj Bhan on request from Jiwan Ram/Deep Chand; brought by Deep Chand and Sisram midnight; attended for 21 days.
Shiv Bhagwan, Durga Parshad paid Rs.50,000 to Dhannaram and Deep Chand.
Lachi Ram, Amar Singh negotiated return of ransom with Deep Chand in presence of Home Minister Chowdhuri Kumbbaram.

Sessions Judge (May 3, 1957): convicted Deep Chand under ss.347,365,386 IPC (1yr,2yr,3.5yr RI concurrent); acquitted under s.458; acquitted Ramji Lal, Dhannaram, Jiwan Ram; convicted Sisram under 347,365 (later acquitted by HC).

Rajasthan High Court (Aug 1, 1958): upheld convictions under 347,365,386; enhanced to 3yr, confirmed 2yr, 8yr + Rs.20,000 fine; convicted under s.452 (7yr RI), s.352; held Deep Chand participated in abduction.

Suraj Bhan's inconsistent statements: Shiv Dutt's s.164 statement Feb 14,1955 (Suraj told prosecution version); Suraj's police statement Mar12,1955 (Ex.D-8 different); affidavit Apr29,1955 (Deep Chand innocent); implicated Deep Chand May23,1956.

legal_issues.text: Whether High Court erred in relying on Suraj Bhan's statement to Magistrate during verification proceedings not recorded under s.164 CrPC, and if excluded, whether confinement in Deep Chand's house proved.
Whether High Court erred in upholding privilege claim by District Magistrate Gajender Singh on cross-examination questions.
Whether High Court erred in setting aside acquittal under s.458 IPC and convicting under s.452 IPC without sufficient reasons.
Admissibility of Magistrate's memorandum Ex.P-27 and evidence under s.9 Evidence Act vs s.164 CrPC.

petitioner_arguments.text: High Court erred in relying on Suraj Bhan's statement before Magistrate at verification not recorded under s.164 CrPC; excluding it, no basis to accept confinement evidence.
High Court erred in upholding privilege by Gajender Singh; answers would show Suraj Bhan lying, prior statements true.
High Court erred in setting aside acquittal under s.458 IPC, convicting under s.452 without compelling reasons.
Sessions Judge's sentences reasonable; High Court unjustified in enhancing.

respondent_arguments.text: Overwhelming evidence of confinement in Deep Chand's house and extortion; identification reliable as Suraj knew Deep Chand.
Inconsistent statements explained by fear for life and recovering ransom.

court_reasoning.text: Concurrent findings of fact by lower courts accepted; no exceptional circumstances to interfere.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Overwhelming evidence of detention, extortion, and participation in abduction.

court_reasoning.text: Magistrate's evidence on facts establishing identity (house condition, chinks, new rooms) admissible under s.9 Evidence Act; statements not recorded under s.164 CrPC inadmissible, but exclusion wouldn't change result due to corroboration.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Distinction: facts observed by Magistrate relevant; unrecorded statements not.

court_reasoning.text: Privilege issue not raised before High Court; courts explained inconsistencies without relying on Gajender Singh primarily.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Evidence of Shiv Dutt accepted; family delayed due to life/ransom concerns.

court_reasoning.text: Suraj Bhan's identification of Deep Chand reliable (prior knowledge, stature, voice, continuous company); justified setting aside acquittal under s.458, conviction under s.452.
Sessions Judge's sentences disproportionately lenient for heinous crime; High Court rightly enhanced.

holdings.text: Magistrate can depose to relevant facts under s.9 Evidence Act establishing identity; unrecorded statements under s.164 CrPC inadmissible.
Concurrent findings upheld: Deep Chand guilty under ss.347,365,386,452 IPC.
Privilege objection not entertainable as not raised below.
Conviction under s.452 justified over s.458 acquittal.
Enhanced sentences by High Court proper.

precedents_cited.relevance: Where power given to do thing in certain way, must be done that way or not at all; Magistrate cannot give evidence of unrecorded confession.

precedents_cited.case_name: Legal Remembrancer v. Lalit Mohan Singh Roy
precedents_cited.relevance: Magistrate cannot give evidence of unrecorded statement by accused.
Verification proceedings: Magistrate's evidence on facts relevant, but unrecorded statements inadmissible.
Verification report by Magistrate admissible if he testifies; unrecorded statements inadmissible.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Convictions under 347 (wrongful confinement to extort), 365 (kidnapping), 386 (extortion by fear of death), 452 (house-trespass to commit offence); acquitted 458 (lurking house-trespass by night).

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Recording statements during investigation; non-compliance makes statements inadmissible.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal by special leave, upheld High Court's convictions under ss.347,365,386,452 IPC and enhanced sentences (3yr RI s.347, 2yr s.365, 8yr + Rs.20,000 fine s.386, 7yr s.352), confirming guilt in abduction, wrongful confinement, house-trespass, and extortion.

key_quotes.text: "where power is given to do a certain thing in a certain way, the thing must be done in that way or not at all, and other methods of performance are necessarily forbidden."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rule from Nazir Ahmad on s.164 CrPC compliance.

key_quotes.text: The Sessions Judge held that the accused was guilty of a grave and heinous crime and we are surprised that he should have sentenced the accused to undergo rigorous imprisonment for one year under s. 347, 2 years under s. 365 and 3 1/2 years under s. 386
key_quotes.speaker: court
